content.description: A Labrador retriever club has 130 members: 65 black Labs, 44 golden Labs, and 21 chocolate Labs. Pablo is going to perform a chi-square goodness-of-fit test to see if the distribution of Labrador retrievers in the club is the same as the distribution nationally. Pablo is going to test his sample against the following null hypothesis, which reflects the national distribution.
content.question: <math alttext="H sub 0: p sub black equals 0.53, p sub golden equals 0.39, p sub chocolate equals 0.08" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.53</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>d</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.39</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>h</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>e</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.08</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>If the distribution of Labrador retrievers in the club were to match that of the national average, how many of each type of Labrador retriever would Pablo expect to see in his club?

choices.label: Labrador Type Black Golden Chocolate Expected Counts 68.9 50.7 10.4
Labrador Type Black Golden Chocolate Expected Counts 50 33.8 16.2
Labrador Type Black Golden Chocolate Expected Counts 65 44 21
Labrador Type Black Golden Chocolate Expected Counts 43.3 43.3 43.3
Labrador Type Black Golden Chocolate Expected Counts 69 51 10

content.answer: Labrador Type Black Golden Chocolate Expected Counts 68.9 50.7 10.4

topic.text: 8.2: Setting up a Chi-Square Goodness of Fit Test

skill.text: Skill 3.A: Determine relative frequencies, proportions, or probabilities using simulation or calculations.
